elements.content: A left-handed homochiral [CuCl2(L1)] n (1) and two solvated heterochiral [CuCl2(L1)] n ·n(H2O) (2) and [CuBr2(L1)] n ·n(MeOH) (3) one-dimensional helical copper(II) coordination polymers have been self-assembled from Cu(II) with an achiral functionalized 1,2,3-triazole (L1) (L1 = 1-(2-picolyl)-4-(1-(methoxyl)-benzotriazole)-1H-1,2,3-triazole) under different conditions. They have been characterized by single-crystal X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis. Complexes 2 and 3 have been further analyzed by powder XRD, thermogravimetric analysis, and electron paramagnetic resonance. Different conformational twists of the ligand skeleton result in different chiral organizations − a large torsional twist (C−C−O−N) of ∼59.4° in 1 results in a large screw-pitch of ∼45.2 Å, whereas a small twist of ∼6.2° in 2 and 6.7° in 3 results in a short screw-pitch of ∼7.6 and 8.1 Å, respectively. The effect of the lattice solvates (H2O and MeOH) on the change of helical structures has also been described.

They have been characterized by single-crystal X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis. Complexes 2 and 3 have been further analyzed by powder XRD, thermogravimetric analysis, and electron paramagnetic resonance. Different conformational twists of the ligand skeleton result in different chiral organizations - a large torsional twist (C-C-O-N) of ~59.4° in 1 results in a large screw-pitch of ~45.2 Å, whereas a small twist of ~6.2° in 2 and 6.7° in 3 results in a short screw-pitch of ~7.6 and 8.1 Å, respectively. The effect of the lattice solvates (H2O and MeOH) on the change of helical structures has also been described.

elements.content: Homochiral left-handed and two heterochiral copper coordination polymers have been crystallized with different helical structures under different solvate conditions by using a heterodifunctional 1,2,3-triazole ligand.
elements.clean_text: Homochiral left-handed and two heterochiral copper coordination polymers have been crystallized with different helical structures under different solvate conditions by using a heterodifunctional 1,2,3-triazole ligand.

elements.content: Chirality is central in the assembly and construction of biological and chemical materials, both in their natural and synthetic forms. Among the chiral materials, there is strong interest in the design of chiral coordination polymers especially by the use of common achiral components without any chiral auxiliaries, driven mainly by their potential applications in catalysis as well as nonlinear optical and magnetic devices. To date, there are only a few examples of spontaneous resolution in which the chiral information of the building blocks can be transmitted into higher dimensionality or generate chiral coordination polymers. The physical principles that govern spontaneous resolution or conformation polymorphism are still not well-defined. In this paper, we report the synthesis of a new nitrogen-rich polydentate triazole ligand from the established copper catalyzed azide−alkyne cycloaddition reaction (CuAAC) and its use as an achiral ligand to generate homo- and heterochiral coordination polymers with Cu(II) through simple and spontaneous self-assembly methodology. This is achieved by taking advantage of the skeletal twist of the flexible σ bridgehead between the two donor functions, namely, pyridyl-triazole and benzotriazole, which lock and introduce a chiral conformation to the resultant polymer. Triazole ligands have found wide applications in coordination complexes, for example, in reversible redox Fe(II) and luminescent Eu(III), Pd(II), and Pt(II) optical π-conjugated system, electro-optical active Ir(III), and various coordination polymers.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Chirality is central in the assembly and construction of biological and chemical materials, both in their natural and synthetic forms. Among the chiral materials, there is strong interest in the design of chiral coordination polymers especially by the use of common achiral components without any chiral auxiliaries, driven mainly by their potential applications in catalysis as well as nonlinear optical and magnetic devices. To date, there are only a few examples of spontaneous resolution in which the chiral information of the building blocks can be transmitted into higher dimensionality or generate chiral coordination polymers. The physical principles that govern spontaneous resolution or conformation polymorphism are still not well-defined. In this paper, we report the synthesis of a new nitrogen-rich polydentate triazole ligand from the established copper catalyzed azide-alkyne cycloaddition reaction (CuAAC) and its use as an achiral ligand to generate homo- and heterochiral coordination polymers with Cu(II) through simple and spontaneous self-assembly methodology. This is achieved by taking advantage of the skeletal twist of the flexible σ bridgehead between the two donor functions, namely, pyridyl-triazole and benzotriazole, which lock and introduce a chiral conformation to the resultant polymer. Triazole ligands have found wide applications in coordination complexes, for example, in reversible redox Fe(II) and luminescent Eu(III), Pd(II), and Pt(II) optical π-conjugated system, electro-optical active Ir(III), and various coordination polymers.

elements.content: All the solvents and chemicals were used as received without further purification. The ligand 1-(2-picolyl)-4-(1-(methoxyl)-benzotriazole)-1H-1,2,3-triazole (L1) was prepared using copper catalyzed “click” chemistry techniques. Elemental analyses were performed on the vario MICRO Elementar system. Infrared spectra were obtained on the Varian 3100 FT-IR spectrometer from samples in KBr discs. NMR spectra were measured at 25 °C using a Bruker ACF 300 NMR spectrometer. Electrospray ionization mass spectrometry (ESI-MS) was recorded in positive ion mode using a thermo Finnigan LCQ spectrometer. Electrospray ionization high resolution mass spectrometry (ESI-HRMS) was recorded on a Finnigan MAT95XL-T. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was carried out using simultaneous DTA-TGA equipment of TA Instruments SDT 2960 with a heating rate of 10 °C/min. Powder X-ray diffraction data were collected on a SIEMENS D5005 X-ray diffractometer with Cu-Kα radiation (λ = 1.5406 Å). Electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) spectra were measured at Nanjing University (P. R. China) using a Bruker ER 200-D-SRC spectrometer at 298 K.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Methods

All the solvents and chemicals were used as received without further purification. The ligand 1-(2-picolyl)-4-(1-(methoxyl)-benzotriazole)-1H-1,2,3-triazole (L1) was prepared using copper catalyzed "click" chemistry techniques. Elemental analyses were performed on the vario MICRO Elementar system. Infrared spectra were obtained on the Varian 3100 FT-IR spectrometer from samples in KBr discs. NMR spectra were measured at 25 °C using a Bruker ACF 300 NMR spectrometer. Electrospray ionization mass spectrometry (ESI-MS) was recorded in positive ion mode using a thermo Finnigan LCQ spectrometer. Electrospray ionization high resolution mass spectrometry (ESI-HRMS) was recorded on a Finnigan MAT95XL-T. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was carried out using simultaneous DTA-TGA equipment of TA Instruments SDT 2960 with a heating rate of 10 °C/min. Powder X-ray diffraction data were collected on a SIEMENS D5005 X-ray diffractometer with Cu-Kα radiation (λ = 1.5406 Å). Electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) spectra were measured at Nanjing University (P. R. China) using a Bruker ER 200-D-SRC spectrometer at 298 K.

elements.content: Caution! 1-Hydroxybenzotriazole has explosion risk especially if heated under confinement. Handlers should take the necessary precautions with suitable shields and protective gear. TGA experiments conducted on 2 and 3 also indicated that these compounds would decompose violently in the range of 140−160 °C.

elements.content: A mixture of 1-hydroxybenzotriazole (0.68 g, 5 mmol), K2CO3 (0.69 g, 5 mmol) and propargyl bromide (1.19 g, 10 mmol) was stirred in MeCN (10 mL) and the reaction was monitored by thin layer chromatography TLC. After ∼10 h when the reaction was completed, the mixture was filtered and the solvent evaporated. The residue was extracted with ethyl acetate (3 × 30 mL) and the extracts were washed with water (3 × 10 mL) and dried over anhydrous Na2SO4. Yield of 1-(prop-2-ynyloxy)-benzotriazole: 0.63 g, 72%. 1H NMR (300 MHz, CDCl3) for C9H7N3O (173.17): δ = 8.02 and 7.99 (d, 1H, J = 8 Hz), 7.70 and 7.67 (d, 1H, J = 8 Hz), 7.48−7.53 (m, 1H), 7.35−7.41 (m, 1H), 5.19 and 5.18 (d, 2H, J = 2 Hz, CH2), 2.574, 2.566, and 2.558 (t, 1H, J = 2 Hz, CH2CCH). 13C NMR (CDCl3, 75 MHz, δ): 128.1, 124.7, 120.1, 109.3 (s, Ar−C), 79.2 (s, CH2 CCH), 75.9 (s, CCH), 67.4 (s, CH2).
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of 1-(2-picolyl)-4-(1-(methoxyl)-benzotriazole)-1H-1,2,3-triazole (L1)

A mixture of 1-hydroxybenzotriazole (0.68 g, 5 mmol), K2CO3 (0.69 g, 5 mmol) and propargyl bromide (1.19 g, 10 mmol) was stirred in MeCN (10 mL) and the reaction was monitored by thin layer chromatography TLC. After ~10 h when the reaction was completed, the mixture was filtered and the solvent evaporated. The residue was extracted with ethyl acetate (3 × 30 mL) and the extracts were washed with water (3 × 10 mL) and dried over anhydrous Na2SO4. Yield of 1-(prop-2-ynyloxy)-benzotriazole: 0.63 g, 72%. 1H NMR (300 MHz, CDCl3) for C9H7N3O (173.17): δ = 8.02 and 7.99 (d, 1H, J = 8 Hz), 7.70 and 7.67 (d, 1H, J = 8 Hz), 7.48-7.53 (m, 1H), 7.35-7.41 (m, 1H), 5.19 and 5.18 (d, 2H, J = 2 Hz, CH2), 2.574, 2.566, and 2.558 (t, 1H, J = 2 Hz, CH2CCH). 13C NMR (CDCl3, 75 MHz, δ): 128.1, 124.7, 120.1, 109.3 (s, Ar-C), 79.2 (s, CH2 CCH), 75.9 (s, CCH), 67.4 (s, CH2).

elements.content: The prepared alkyne viz. 1-(prop-2-ynyloxy)-benzotriazole (0.63 g, 3.6 mmol) was mixed with 2-picolyl chloride hydrochloride (0.59 g, 3.6 mmol) and NaN3 (0.24 g, 3.6 mmol) in a mixture of DMSO/H2O (1:4, 20 mL), followed by the addition of Na2CO3 (0.21 g, 2 mmol), CuSO4·5H2O (0.18 g, 0.7 mmol), and sodium ascorbate (0.20 g, 1.0 mmol). The reaction was stirred at r.t. for 24 h. The residue was extracted with Et2O (3 × 30 mL) and the extracts were washed with water (3 × 10 mL) and dried over anhydrous Na2SO4. The product was purified by column chromatography on silica gel. Yield: 0.18 g, 16%. 1H NMR (300 MHz, CD3CN) for C15H13N7O (307.12): δ = 8.49 and 8.47 (d, 1H, J = 5 Hz), 7.88−7.92 (m, 2H), 7.67−7.73 (m, 1H), 7.22−7.38 (m, 4H), 7.03 and 7.00 (d, 1H, J = 8 Hz), 5.65 (s, 2H, CH2), 5.56 (s, 2H, CH2). 13C NMR (CD3CN, 75 MHz, δ): 155.5, 150.5, 143.9, 141.3, 138.1, 128.8, 127.5, 125.4, 124.1, 122.8, 120.3, and 109.8 (s, Ar−C), 73.5 (s, OCH2), 55.8 (s, CH2Py). ESI-HRMS (m/z) for (L1 + Na+) (C15H13ON7 23Na): 330.1079 (theoretical mass: 330.1074). ESI-MS (m/z, %): [L1 + Na+] (330, 96).

elements.content: A MeOH solution (3 mL) of CuCl2·2H2O (0.017 g, 0.1 mmol) was added into a test tube, after which a mixture of MeCN and Et2O (1:4, 5 mL) was carefully layered above, followed by another layer of an Et2O solution (5 mL) of L1 (0.031 g, 0.1 mmol). Slow diffusion resulted in a few green block crystals of 1 and mainly blue plate-crystals of 2 after ∼3 days. The mixture was allowed to stand for another week, after which powder XRD measurement indicated the bulk sample to be 2. Complex 2 can also be prepared from a MeOH solution (5 mL) of CuCl2·2H2O (0.017 g, 0.1 mmol) and a MeCN solution (5 mL) of L1 (0.031 g, 0.1 mmol). Yield of 2: 18 mg, 39%. Anal. Calcd. for C15H15Cl2CuN7O2 (459.78): C, 39.18; H, 3.29; N, 21.32. Found: C, 38.86; H, 3.28; N, 20.73%. IR (KBr)/cm−1: 1605 (νCC) in aromatic ring; 1444 and 1108 (C−C stretching); 1141 and 1075 (N−N stretching) in 1,2,3-triazole ring. ESI-MS (m/z, %): [CuCl(L1)]+ (405, 72); [CuCl(L1)2]+ (712, 100).

A MeOH solution (3 mL) of CuCl2⋅2H2O (0.017 g, 0.1 mmol) was added into a test tube, after which a mixture of MeCN and Et2O (1:4, 5 mL) was carefully layered above, followed by another layer of an Et2O solution (5 mL) of L1 (0.031 g, 0.1 mmol). Slow diffusion resulted in a few green block crystals of 1 and mainly blue plate-crystals of 2 after ~3 days. The mixture was allowed to stand for another week, after which powder XRD measurement indicated the bulk sample to be 2. Complex 2 can also be prepared from a MeOH solution (5 mL) of CuCl2⋅2H2O (0.017 g, 0.1 mmol) and a MeCN solution (5 mL) of L1 (0.031 g, 0.1 mmol). Yield of 2: 18 mg, 39%. Anal. Calcd. for C15H15Cl2CuN7O2 (459.78): C, 39.18; H, 3.29; N, 21.32. Found: C, 38.86; H, 3.28; N, 20.73%. IR (KBr)/cm-1: 1605 (νCC) in aromatic ring; 1444 and 1108 (C-C stretching); 1141 and 1075 (N-N stretching) in 1,2,3-triazole ring. ESI-MS (m/z, %): [CuCl(L1)]+ (405, 72); [CuCl(L1)2]+ (712, 100).

Slow diffusion over a week resulted in blue block-crystals of 3. Complex 3 can also be prepared from the mixture of a MeOH solution (5 mL) of CuBr2 (0.022 g, 0.1 mmol) and MeCN solution (5 mL) of L1 (0.031 g, 0.1 mmol). Yield: 25 mg, 44%. Anal. Calcd. for C16H17Br2CuN7O2 (562.73): C, 34.15; H, 3.05; N, 17.42. Found: C, 33.99; H, 3.33; N, 18.26%. IR (KBr)/cm−1: 1609 (νCC) in aromatic ring; 1441 and 1109 (C−C stretching); 1145 and 1066 (N−N stretching) in 1,2,3-triazole ring. ESI-MS (m/z, %): [Cu(L1)]2+ (370, 100); [CuBr(L1)2]+ (756, 8).

An aqueous solution (2 mL) of CuBr2 (0.022 g, 0.1 mmol) was added into a test tube, on which was carefully layered a solution of L1 (0.031 g, 0.1 mmol) in a mixture of MeCN and MeOH (1:1, 4 mL). Slow diffusion over a week resulted in blue block-crystals of 3. Complex 3 can also be prepared from the mixture of a MeOH solution (5 mL) of CuBr2 (0.022 g, 0.1 mmol) and MeCN solution (5 mL) of L1 (0.031 g, 0.1 mmol). Yield: 25 mg, 44%. Anal. Calcd. for C16H17Br2CuN7O2 (562.73): C, 34.15; H, 3.05; N, 17.42. Found: C, 33.99; H, 3.33; N, 18.26%. elements.content: All measurements were conducted on a Bruker AXS SMART APEX diffractometer, equipped with a CCD area-detector using Mo−Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) (Table ). The collecting frames of data, indexing reflection, and determination of lattice parameters and polarization effects were performed with the SMART suite programs. The integration of intensity of reflections and scaling was carried out by SAINT. The empirical absorption correction was performed by SADABS. The space group determination, structure solution, and least-squares refinements on |F|2 were carried out with the SHELXS-97 and SHELXL-97. The structures were solved by direct methods to locate the heavy atoms, followed by difference maps for the light non-hydrogen atoms. Anisotropic thermal parameters were refined for the rest of the non-hydrogen atoms. Hydrogen atoms were placed geometrically and refined isotropically. CCDC numbers: 743454 (1), 743455 (2), and 743456 (3).
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Structure Determination

All measurements were conducted on a Bruker AXS SMART APEX diffractometer, equipped with a CCD area-detector using Mo-Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) (Table ). The collecting frames of data, indexing reflection, and determination of lattice parameters and polarization effects were performed with the SMART suite programs. The integration of intensity of reflections and scaling was carried out by SAINT. The empirical absorption correction was performed by SADABS. The space group determination, structure solution, and least-squares refinements on |F|2 were carried out with the SHELXS-97 and SHELXL-97. The structures were solved by direct methods to locate the heavy atoms, followed by difference maps for the light non-hydrogen atoms. Anisotropic thermal parameters were refined for the rest of the non-hydrogen atoms. Hydrogen atoms were placed geometrically and refined isotropically. CCDC numbers: 743454 (1), 743455 (2), and 743456 (3).

The ligand 1-(2-picolyl)-4-(1-(methoxyl)-benzotriazole)-1H-1,2,3-triazole (L1) was prepared from the click-inspired copper-catalyzed azide−alkyne cycloaddition reaction of 2-picolyl chloride hydrochloride, NaN3, and the alkyne (1-(prop-2-ynyloxy)-benzotriazole) catalyzed by CuSO4 in the presence of sodium ascorbate as the reducing agent and Na2CO3 as the base (Scheme ). The reaction of L1 with CuCl2·2H2O in a mixture of MeOH, Et2O, and MeCN can give a few green block-crystals of [CuCl2(L1)] n (1), but the main product is blue plate-crystals of [CuCl2(L1)] n ·n(H2O) (2). Complex 1 is probably a kinetic product, whereas 2 is a thermodynamic product. They are chemically identical but crystallographically differentiable. Repeated attempts to convert 2 to 1 in the aprotic solvents MeCN and DCM were unsuccessful. Compound L1 reacts with CuBr2 in a mixture of MeOH, MeCN, and H2O to give blue block-crystals of [CuBr2(L1)] n ·n(MeOH) (3). Both 2 and 3 can also form from a 1:1 mixture of MeOH solution of CuCl2·2H2O or CuBr2 and MeCN solution of L1.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Synthesis

The ligand 1-(2-picolyl)-4-(1-(methoxyl)-benzotriazole)-1H-1,2,3-triazole (L1) was prepared from the click-inspired copper-catalyzed azide-alkyne cycloaddition reaction of 2-picolyl chloride hydrochloride, NaN3, and the alkyne (1-(prop-2-ynyloxy)-benzotriazole) catalyzed by CuSO4 in the presence of sodium ascorbate as the reducing agent and Na2CO3 as the base (Scheme ). The reaction of L1 with CuCl2⋅2H2O in a mixture of MeOH, Et2O, and MeCN can give a few green block-crystals of [CuCl2(L1)] n  (1), but the main product is blue plate-crystals of [CuCl2(L1)] n ⋅n(H2O) (2). Complex 1 is probably a kinetic product, whereas 2 is a thermodynamic product. They are chemically identical but crystallographically differentiable. Repeated attempts to convert 2 to 1 in the aprotic solvents MeCN and DCM were unsuccessful. Compound L1 reacts with CuBr2 in a mixture of MeOH, MeCN, and H2O to give blue block-crystals of [CuBr2(L1)] n ⋅n(MeOH) (3). Both 2 and 3 can also form from a 1:1 mixture of MeOH solution of CuCl2⋅2H2O or CuBr2 and MeCN solution of L1.

elements.clean_text: 1  Synthetic Scheme of Ligand L1 and 1-D Coordination Polymeric Cu(II) Complexes 1-3

elements.content: The single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis of 1−3 shows a 1-D coordination polymer of Cu(II) bridged exclusively by the N-bonded heterocyclic ligand with triazole-pyridyl chelate on one end and monodentate benzotriazole at the other (Figures − ). With two terminal halides, each Cu(II) is thus 5-coordinated showing a distorted square-pyramidal geometry (structural indices τ = 0.47) for 1 (Cu1 deviates from the basal plane (N1−N7A−Cl1−Cl2) by −0.3041 Å and N3−Cu1 174.7° to this plane) and trigonal bipyramidal in 2 and 3 (similar structural indices τ = 0.64 for both 2 and 3, and the Cu1 deviates from the basal plane (Cl1−Cl2−N3) and (Br1−Br2−N3) by 0.0113 and 0.0129 Å for 2 and 3, respectively). They show extensive intermolecular hydrogen-bonding interactions (Table ).

X-ray Crystal and Molecular Structures of 1-3 

The single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis of 1-3 shows a 1-D coordination polymer of Cu(II) bridged exclusively by the N-bonded heterocyclic ligand with triazole-pyridyl chelate on one end and monodentate benzotriazole at the other (Figures - ). With two terminal halides, each Cu(II) is thus 5-coordinated showing a distorted square-pyramidal geometry (structural indices τ = 0.47) for 1 (Cu1 deviates from the basal plane (N1-N7A-Cl1-Cl2) by -0.3041 Å and N3-Cu1 174.7° to this plane) and trigonal bipyramidal in 2 and 3 (similar structural indices τ = 0.64 for both 2 and 3, and the Cu1 deviates from the basal plane (Cl1-Cl2-N3) and (Br1-Br2-N3) by 0.0113 and 0.0129 Å for 2 and 3, respectively). They show extensive intermolecular hydrogen-bonding interactions (Table ).

elements.content: Complexes 1 and 2 crystallize in different space groups − the chiral space group P65 for 1 and nonchiral P21/c for 2. In 1, the main ligand skeleton that connects the two donor groups, viz. C8−C9−O1−N5, gives a torsion angle of ∼59.4°, which helps to extend the one-dimensional left-hand helical polymeric strand in the c direction with a large screw-pitch of ∼45.2 Å (Figure b). Interestingly, these helices spontaneously assemble into a homochiral 3-D packing network (Figure c,d). Similar behavior was also observed in the azide-bridged 1-D Mn(II) complexes [Mn3(L1)2(N3)6] n (I) and [Mn2(L2)2(N3)3] n ·n(ClO4)·n(H2O) (II) (L1 = 1,4-bis(2-pyridyl)-1-amino-2,3-diaza-1,3-butadiene and L2 = 1,4-bis(2-pyridyl)-1,4-diamino-2,3-diaza-1,3-butadiene). Hydrogen bonding interactions between the neighboring chains are evident (C3−H···Cl1 3.55 and C6−H···Cl1 3.48 Å) (Table and Figure c).

elements.content: Complexes 2 (Figure ) and 3 (Figure ) (space group P21/c) crystallize with one lattice H2O and MeOH molecules in each asymmetric unit, respectively. Their overall helical polymeric structures are similar to that of 1 except that the Cu(II) center are closer to a distorted trigonal bipyramidal form. The small torsion angles of C8−C9−O1−N5 (∼6.2 and 6.7°) of L1 in 2 and 3, respectively, coupling with short screw-pitches of ∼7.6 and 8.1 Å mark striking difference with 1. These results in equal mixture of both left- and right-handed helices and the presence of 21 helical axis in the racemates of 2 and 3.

elements.content: Solids 1 and 2 come from the same reaction system, but they crystallize in different space groups and chiral outcomes. The latter crystallizes with a H2O hydrate in the lattice. This lattice water holds the two neighboring polymer strands together through H-bonding (O1W−H1WA···N4 2.95, O1W−H1WB···O1 3.25, C7−H···O1W 3.24, and C15−H···O1W 3.27 Å) (Table and Figure a). The hydrate serves as electron acceptor to one strand and donor to the other. This H-bonding between the hydrate and polymer is further supplemented by interpolymer H-bonding between the coordinated chloride with the hydrogen atoms in its neighboring polymer (C6−H···Cl2 3.56 and C7−H···Cl2 3.41 Å) in the c and (C3−H···Cl1 3.53 Å) in the a direction (Figures c and a). The lattice MeOH also shows H-bonding with the polymeric chain (O1S−H1S···N4 2.92 and C1S−H1S1···O1 3.09 Å) (Figure b). Additional intermolecular H-bonding interactions (C3−H···Br2 3.63 and C7−H···Br1 3.58 Å) are also evident among the neighboring chains in 3 (Figures c and b). A related system is found in [Mn2(L3)(N3)4] n (III) and [Mn2(L3)(N3)4] n ·n(MeOH) (IV) (L3 = 2,5-bis(2-pyridyl)-3,4-diaza-2,4-hexadiene), both of which contain chiral layers, although they are different polymeric dimensionalities (2-D in III and IV and 1-D in 1 and 2). The solvate induces an opposite effect as seen in the chiral chains of 1 and 2. In the unsolvated form III, the adjacent layers, which interact through weak π···π stacking interaction of the pyridyl rings, are related by an inversion center, thus resulting in an overall racemic structure. For IV, the adjacent layers, which are weakly interacting with the MeOH solvate, are packed with a 31 screw, thus giving an overall chiral solid.

elements.content: Solid X-band EPR spectra were recorded for 2 and 3 at 298 K (Figure ). Both complexes 2 and 3 show three g-value anisotropic EPR patterns with g 1 = 2.25, g 2 = 2.13, and g 3 = 2.04 for 2 and g 1 = 2.21, g 2 = 2.13, and g 3 = 2.04 for 3. Their experimental and calculated X-ray powder diffraction patterns show good agreement, supporting good phase purity (Figure ). The thermogravimetric (TG) profiles of L1, 2, and 3 from r.t. to 700 °C (under air or N2 flow) are given in Figure . The ligand L1, which remains intact up to ∼200 °C, is significantly more stable than its complexes 2 and 3, which decompose at temperatures < 160 °C. At higher temperatures (>350 °C), L1 decomposes more readily in air, probably because of the oxidation of the triazole rings. Decomposition in either atmosphere is complete at ∼650 °C leaving little residues. Its complexes, in either air or N2, decompose more readily but yield higher residues due to the metal (and oxide) contents. Complexes 2 and 3 are stable up to ∼140 and 130 °C, respectively, except losing the solvate [∼4.7% (calcd. 3.9%) of H2O in 2 and ∼4.5% (calcd. 5.7%) of MeOH in 3]. Above ∼140 °C, there is a dramatic weight loss both in air or N2 over a short temperature range (of ∼16.9 or 18.8% and 17.6 or 26.9% for 2 and 3 respectively over ∼154−159 and 144−149 °C). This can be attributed to explosive oxidative degradation of the nitrogen-rich ligand in the presence of Cu(II).

EPR, Powder XRD, and TGA

Solid X-band EPR spectra were recorded for 2 and 3 at 298 K (Figure ). Both complexes 2 and 3 show three g-value anisotropic EPR patterns with g 1 = 2.25, g 2 = 2.13, and g 3 = 2.04 for 2 and g 1 = 2.21, g 2 = 2.13, and g 3 = 2.04 for 3. Their experimental and calculated X-ray powder diffraction patterns show good agreement, supporting good phase purity (Figure ). The thermogravimetric (TG) profiles of L1, 2, and 3 from r.t. to 700 °C (under air or N2 flow) are given in Figure . The ligand L1, which remains intact up to ~200 °C, is significantly more stable than its complexes 2 and 3, which decompose at temperatures < 160 °C. At higher temperatures (>350 °C), L1 decomposes more readily in air, probably because of the oxidation of the triazole rings. Decomposition in either atmosphere is complete at ~650 °C leaving little residues. Its complexes, in either air or N2, decompose more readily but yield higher residues due to the metal (and oxide) contents. Complexes 2 and 3 are stable up to ~140 and 130 °C, respectively, except losing the solvate [~4.7% (calcd. 3.9%) of H2O in 2 and ~4.5% (calcd. 5.7%) of MeOH in 3]. Above ~140 °C, there is a dramatic weight loss both in air or N2 over a short temperature range (of ~16.9 or 18.8% and 17.6 or 26.9% for 2 and 3 respectively over ~154-159 and 144-149 °C). This can be attributed to explosive oxidative degradation of the nitrogen-rich ligand in the presence of Cu(II).

elements.content: The two nitrogen ligands, viz. triazole-pyridyl and benzotriazole of 1, extend in approximately opposite directions at the metal center (the dihedral angle between the benzotriazole-Cu1 plane and Cu1−N1−N3 plane is 162.3°). On the other hand, for 2 and 3, the same angle (45.1 and 43.4°, respectively) is much more acute. This different direction of propagation together with the significantly different solvate-constraint rotation of the O1−C9 bridgehead suggests that the solvate provides an external influence in the helical extension of a system that is inherently flexible. Such flexibility is inherited from the geometrically adjustable Cu(II) in conjunction with a skeletally adaptable spacer. The spontaneous resolution in 1 is probably assisted by the interstrand H-bonding interactions, such that the left-hand helical chains are parallel to each other in an overall homochiral 3-D supramolecular structure (Figure c,d). For 2 and 3, although each 1-D strand is chiral, the neighboring strands are connected through H-bonding and related by 21 axis to give overall centrosymmetric structures (Figures c, c, and ).
elements.clean_text:
Skeletally Flexible Bridges

The two nitrogen ligands, viz. triazole-pyridyl and benzotriazole of 1, extend in approximately opposite directions at the metal center (the dihedral angle between the benzotriazole-Cu1 plane and Cu1-N1-N3 plane is 162.3°). On the other hand, for 2 and 3, the same angle (45.1 and 43.4°, respectively) is much more acute. This different direction of propagation together with the significantly different solvate-constraint rotation of the O1-C9 bridgehead suggests that the solvate provides an external influence in the helical extension of a system that is inherently flexible. Such flexibility is inherited from the geometrically adjustable Cu(II) in conjunction with a skeletally adaptable spacer. The spontaneous resolution in 1 is probably assisted by the interstrand H-bonding interactions, such that the left-hand helical chains are parallel to each other in an overall homochiral 3-D supramolecular structure (Figure c,d). For 2 and 3, although each 1-D strand is chiral, the neighboring strands are connected through H-bonding and related by 21 axis to give overall centrosymmetric structures (Figures c, c, and ).

elements.content: The two coordinatively different ends of the bridging ligand impose a dissymmetry at each copper center along the polymer chain. A similar design was reported by Chen et al. who used the polypyridyl bridges to create homochiral crystallization. However, the key difference here is the exploitation of the conformational twist of the backbone that links the two different triazole moieties within the ligand to achieve chiral organization. At an extended state with a large torsional angle, the polymer propagates unidirectionally with a large screw-pitch to give a homochiral crystal. At a closed state with an acute torsional angle supported by H-bonding with the lattice solvate, the polymer embraces itself and self-selects a heterochiral association to give racemic crystals. Unlike the Ag(I) system, which also generates homo- and heterochiral coordination polymers, there is no M−M bonding assistance in our system, and that the bridging ligand is skeletally more flexible than the diaminocyclohexane used to support Ag(I). Our system also utilizes an extensive H-bonding network, between the solvate and polymer chain as well as among the neighboring polymer strands, to promote the assembly. Such chiral organization has been reported in the organic guanidinium-sulfonate inclusion systems. Similar “self-sorting” of homochiral supramolecular single crystals from achiral building blocks has also been reported recently.

elements.content: These helical coordination polymeric assemblies are achieved through the combinative use of metals that are geometrically flexible and the triazole spacers that are coordinatively adaptive. The dual chelating and bridging modes of the latter provides an additional flexibility in coordination. Spontaneous resolution was observed in 1, whereas the solvated forms result in racemates in 2 and 3. We are currently exploiting the use of click techniques to design other forms of bifunctional extended spacers that can support both polymerization and chiral organization.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

These helical coordination polymeric assemblies are achieved through the combinative use of metals that are geometrically flexible and the triazole spacers that are coordinatively adaptive. The dual chelating and bridging modes of the latter provides an additional flexibility in coordination. Spontaneous resolution was observed in 1, whereas the solvated forms result in racemates in 2 and 3. We are currently exploiting the use of click techniques to design other forms of bifunctional extended spacers that can support both polymerization and chiral organization.

A mixture of 1-hydroxybenzotriazole (0.68 g, 5 mmol), K2CO3 (0.69 g, 5 mmol) and propargyl bromide (1.19 g, 10 mmol) was stirred in MeCN (10 mL) and the reaction was monitored by thin layer chromatography TLC. After ∼10 h when the reaction was completed, the mixture was filtered and the solvent evaporated. The residue was extracted with ethyl acetate (3 × 30 mL) and the extracts were washed with water (3 × 10 mL) and dried over anhydrous Na2SO4. Yield of 1-(prop-2-ynyloxy)-benzotriazole: 0.63 g, 72%. 1H NMR (300 MHz, CDCl3) for C9H7N3O (173.17): δ = 8.02 and 7.99 (d, 1H, J = 8 Hz), 7.70 and 7.67 (d, 1H, J = 8 Hz), 7.48−7.53 (m, 1H), 7.35−7.41 (m, 1H), 5.19 and 5.18 (d, 2H, J = 2 Hz, CH2), 2.574, 2.566, and 2.558 (t, 1H, J = 2 Hz, CH2CCH). 13C NMR (CDCl3, 75 MHz, δ): 128.1, 124.7, 120.1, 109.3 (s, Ar−C), 79.2 (s, CH2 CCH), 75.9 (s, CCH), 67.4 (s, CH2).

The prepared alkyne viz. 1-(prop-2-ynyloxy)-benzotriazole (0.63 g, 3.6 mmol) was mixed with 2-picolyl chloride hydrochloride (0.59 g, 3.6 mmol) and NaN3 (0.24 g, 3.6 mmol) in a mixture of DMSO/H2O (1:4, 20 mL), followed by the addition of Na2CO3 (0.21 g, 2 mmol), CuSO4·5H2O (0.18 g, 0.7 mmol), and sodium ascorbate (0.20 g, 1.0 mmol). The reaction was stirred at r.t. for 24 h. The residue was extracted with Et2O (3 × 30 mL) and the extracts were washed with water (3 × 10 mL) and dried over anhydrous Na2SO4. The product was purified by column chromatography on silica gel. Yield: 0.18 g, 16%. 1H NMR (300 MHz, CD3CN) for C15H13N7O (307.12): δ = 8.49 and 8.47 (d, 1H, J = 5 Hz), 7.88−7.92 (m, 2H), 7.67−7.73 (m, 1H), 7.22−7.38 (m, 4H), 7.03 and 7.00 (d, 1H, J = 8 Hz), 5.65 (s, 2H, CH2), 5.56 (s, 2H, CH2). 13C NMR (CD3CN, 75 MHz, δ): 155.5, 150.5, 143.9, 141.3, 138.1, 128.8, 127.5, 125.4, 124.1, 122.8, 120.3, and 109.8 (s, Ar−C), 73.5 (s, OCH2), 55.8 (s, CH2Py). ESI-HRMS (m/z) for (L1 + Na+) (C15H13ON7 23Na): 330.1079 (theoretical mass: 330.1074). ESI-MS (m/z, %): [L1 + Na+] (330, 96).

Synthesis of [CuCl<sub>2</sub>(L1)]<sub> <italic toggle="yes">n</italic> </sub> (<bold>1</bold>) and [CuCl<sub>2</sub>(L1)]<sub> <italic toggle="yes">n</italic> </sub>·<italic toggle="yes">n</italic>(H<sub>2</sub>O) (<bold>2</bold>)

A MeOH solution (3 mL) of CuCl2·2H2O (0.017 g, 0.1 mmol) was added into a test tube, after which a mixture of MeCN and Et2O (1:4, 5 mL) was carefully layered above, followed by another layer of an Et2O solution (5 mL) of L1 (0.031 g, 0.1 mmol). Slow diffusion resulted in a few green block crystals of 1 and mainly blue plate-crystals of 2 after ∼3 days. The mixture was allowed to stand for another week, after which powder XRD measurement indicated the bulk sample to be 2. Complex 2 can also be prepared from a MeOH solution (5 mL) of CuCl2·2H2O (0.017 g, 0.1 mmol) and a MeCN solution (5 mL) of L1 (0.031 g, 0.1 mmol). Yield of 2: 18 mg, 39%. Anal. Calcd. for C15H15Cl2CuN7O2 (459.78): C, 39.18; H, 3.29; N, 21.32. Found: C, 38.86; H, 3.28; N, 20.73%. IR (KBr)/cm−1: 1605 (νCC) in aromatic ring; 1444 and 1108 (C−C stretching); 1141 and 1075 (N−N stretching) in 1,2,3-triazole ring. ESI-MS (m/z, %): [CuCl(L1)]+ (405, 72); [CuCl(L1)2]+ (712, 100).

Synthesis of [CuBr<sub>2</sub>(L1)]<sub> <italic toggle="yes">n</italic> </sub>·<italic toggle="yes">n</italic>(MeOH) (<bold>3</bold>)

An aqueous solution (2 mL) of CuBr2 (0.022 g, 0.1 mmol) was added into a test tube, on which was carefully layered a solution of L1 (0.031 g, 0.1 mmol) in a mixture of MeCN and MeOH (1:1, 4 mL). Slow diffusion over a week resulted in blue block-crystals of 3. Complex 3 can also be prepared from the mixture of a MeOH solution (5 mL) of CuBr2 (0.022 g, 0.1 mmol) and MeCN solution (5 mL) of L1 (0.031 g, 0.1 mmol). Yield: 25 mg, 44%. Anal. Calcd. for C16H17Br2CuN7O2 (562.73): C, 34.15; H, 3.05; N, 17.42. Found: C, 33.99; H, 3.33; N, 18.26%. IR (KBr)/cm−1: 1609 (νCC) in aromatic ring; 1441 and 1109 (C−C stretching); 1145 and 1066 (N−N stretching) in 1,2,3-triazole ring. ESI-MS (m/z, %): [Cu(L1)]2+ (370, 100); [CuBr(L1)2]+ (756, 8).

cln_elements.content: Solid X-band EPR spectra were recorded for 2 and 3 at 298 K (Figure ). Both complexes 2 and 3 show three g-value anisotropic EPR patterns with g 1 = 2.25, g 2 = 2.13, and g 3 = 2.04 for 2 and g 1 = 2.21, g 2 = 2.13, and g 3 = 2.04 for 3. Their experimental and calculated X-ray powder diffraction patterns show good agreement, supporting good phase purity (Figure ). The thermogravimetric (TG) profiles of L1, 2, and 3 from r.t. to 700 °C (under air or N2 flow) are given in Figure . The ligand L1, which remains intact up to ∼200 °C, is significantly more stable than its complexes 2 and 3, which decompose at temperatures < 160 °C. At higher temperatures (>350 °C), L1 decomposes more readily in air, probably because of the oxidation of the triazole rings. Decomposition in either atmosphere is complete at ∼650 °C leaving little residues. Its complexes, in either air or N2, decompose more readily but yield higher residues due to the metal (and oxide) contents. Complexes 2 and 3 are stable up to ∼140 and 130 °C, respectively, except losing the solvate [∼4.7% (calcd. 3.9%) of H2O in 2 and ∼4.5% (calcd. 5.7%) of MeOH in 3]. Above ∼140 °C, there is a dramatic weight loss both in air or N2 over a short temperature range (of ∼16.9 or 18.8% and 17.6 or 26.9% for 2 and 3 respectively over ∼154−159 and 144−149 °C). This can be attributed to explosive oxidative degradation of the nitrogen-rich ligand in the presence of Cu(II).
